content: Featured Steve Wozniak, co-founder of Apple Inc., as the conference's first keynote speaker.
Introduction of MechMania, a 24-hour AI hackathon competition. Students competed to create an AI agent to play a modified game of capture the flag.
Adopted the “Reflections | Projections” theme.
Sponsors included AMD, Boeing, Intel, Citrix Systems.

Our conference included talks about OpenGL, web commerce, and Y2K. OpenGL, a cross-language, cross-platform API for 2D and 3D vector graphics rendering, continues to be the an industry standard for high performance graphics.
Official adoption of the name “Reflections | Projections”.
Took on the title of National Student ACM Conference, reaching 350 students from 12 universities, and over 45 corporate sponsors.

Keynote talk by Fred Brooks, known for heading developing of IBM System/360 family of computers and OS/360 software support package. Two years prior to speaking at R|P 2001, Brooks received the Turing Award.

General talks by John Draper and Alexy Pajitnov. Draper was a widely known figure in the hacker community who, among other things, exposed a vulnerability in the AT&T network using a toy whistle packaged in boxes of Cap'n Crunch cereal. Pajitnov created Tetris.
Included workshops on Windows and Perl.
Included a PGP key signing party.
Talks by Michael Hatt, Ian Murdock, Marcus Brinkmann, and Hal Berghel
Additional sponsors included Microsoft, Abbott Laboratories, and Argonne National Laboratory
The year of cryptography, security, and multimedia
Talk by ACM national lecturer Barbara Simons on computerized and Internet voting

Had a creative portion, where undergraduates were invited to submit research projects or ideas to present as posters. The projects included open-source development, independent study, & semester group projects.
Speakers included Jimmy Wales, Thomas Cormen, and Owen Astracham
Featured talks from Jawed Karim, co-founder of YouTube, and Max Levchin, co-founder of PayPal.
Theme change.

Heavily expanded corporate presence at the conference. Sponsors included Bloomberg, Caterpillar Inc., Cerner, Citadel LLC, Facebook, Intel, Microsoft, Navteq, Northrop Grumman, the NSA, Nvidia, Raytheon, Sun Microsystems, SpaceX, VMware, Yahoo and others
Beginning of the Startup Fair.
Broke previous attendance records, hosting nearly 2000 attendees.
A year of innovation, entrepreneurship, and brilliance.
Reintroduction of the ACM Symposium, a showcase of projects and research by the UIUC computer science community.

list.name: Sri Shivananda
list.bio: Sri Shivananda plays a critical role in helping PayPal remain at the forefront of innovation as PayPal’s SVP, Chief Technology Officer (CTO). In his role, Sri oversees Technology Platforms & Experiences, leading a talented team responsible for the company’s secure, reliable and scalable global infrastructure and strategic core platform, the foundation that enables PayPal to deliver innovative products and services to consumers and merchants all over the world. Prior to his appointment as SVP and CTO, Sri was Vice President of Global Platform and Infrastructure, directing his team of technologists to drive massive growth at scale across a completely disruptive payments platform. Sri was responsible for all core technologies covering PayPal’s data centers, internal private cloud, online and offline data infrastructure, internal developer frameworks and tools, and various platform services. Before PayPal, Sri was with eBay for more than 15 years, working his way up from a software engineer to Vice President of Global Platform and Infrastructure. As VP, he was responsible for the company’s technology infrastructure that powered the eBay Inc. businesses, including eBay’s hundreds of millions of listings and PayPal’s millions of payments every day. Sri found his way to eBay via the acquisition of Deja.com. Sri is a geek at heart and his passion for learning is evident – he’s constantly pushing the boundaries of innovation, encouraging creative ideas and solutions that solve complex problems with technology.

list.name: Ayanna Howard
list.tagline: Chair, School of Interactive Computing @ Georgia Tech & Founder and CTO @ Zyrobotics
list.bio: Ayanna Howard, Ph.D. is Professor and Chair of the School of Interactive Computing at the Georgia Institute of Technology. She is also the Chief Technology Officer of Zyrobotics. Dr. Howard’s career focus is on intelligent technologies that must adapt to and function within a human-centered world. Her work, which encompasses advancements in artificial intelligence (AI), assistive technologies, and robotics, has resulted in over 250 peer-reviewed publications. To date, her unique accomplishments have been highlighted through a number of awards and articles, including highlights in USA Today, Upscale, and TIME Magazine, as well as being recognized as one of the 23 most powerful women engineers in the world by Business Insider and one of the Top 50 U.S. Women in Tech by Forbes. Prior to Georgia Tech, Dr. Howard was a senior robotics researcher and deputy manager in the Office of the Chief Scientist at NASA's JPL.

list.name: Mallory Knodel
list.tagline: CTO @ the Center for Democracy and Technology
list.bio: Mallory Knodel is the Chief Technology Officer for the Center for Democracy & Technology. She is the co-chair of the Human Rights and Protocol Considerations research group of the Internet Research Task Force and a chairing advisor to the Freedom Online Coalition. Mallory takes a human rights, people-centred approach to technology implementation and cybersecurity policy advocacy. Originally from the US, having lived extensively in Nairobi before relocating to DC, she has worked with grassroots organisations around the world in Bolivia, France, Palestine and the UK. She has used free software throughout her professional career and considers herself a public interest technologist. She holds a BS in Physics and Mathematics and an MA in Science Education.

list.name: Tatiana Arthur Murphy
list.tagline: Chief of Staff for Global People Sustainability & Diversity and Inclusion @ SAP

list.name: Saleema Amershi
list.bio: Saleema Amershi is a Principal Researcher at Microsoft Research AI and currently chairs Microsoft's Aether Working Group on Human-AI Interaction and Collaboration. Aether is Microsoft’s advisory committee on responsible and ethical AI. Saleema's research focuses on helping people create effective and responsible AI user experiences. Her recent work includes leading Microsoft's effort to develop general Guidelines for Human-AI Interaction, a unified and validated set of guidelines to establish a foundation for human-AI interaction design. Throughout the years, she has developed tools and methodologies to support practitioners in designing and building AI-based products and services, including general purpose platforms and visualizations for data scientists building predictive models, and application specific techniques for supporting end-users interacting with AI-systems in their everyday lives.

list.name: Angela Hooker
list.bio: Angela M. Hooker is a program creator who develops centers of experience and excellence for digital accessibility inclusion programs. She's brought her web management, development, accessibility, and editorial and content management expertise to the private sector and government for over 20 years. When she's not pushing for world domination through accessibility, Angela spends her time perfecting recipes for her first cookbook, attending concerts (now virtually), and playing guitar—badly. She might even sing (also badly) during her session.

list.name: Aaron Saunders
list.tagline: CEO @ Clearly Innovative Inc. & Inclusive Innovation Incubator
list.bio: Aaron Saunders is the CEO of the Inclusive Innovation Incubator and Innovation space focused on supporting high potential Black and underrepresented technologist entrepreneurs and creatives through programs, services and space. He is also the Founder and CEO of Clearly Innovative Inc, a web and mobile development firm with 10+ years of experience in Washington DC, and mobile partner for the National Museum of African American History and Culture.

list.name: Yasyf Mohamedali
list.bio: Yasyf is the CEO and founder of Sym, a workflow automation platform that empowers teams to build perfect security and privacy controls. His last adventure was a healthcare startup: Karuna. Karuna builds software that automates common care management tasks. He recently finished his Master's and undergrad at MIT, exploring the intersection of Venture and CS while working in tandem with First Round to build the one-stop shop for first time founders raising seed rounds. He also supported student founders around MIT and Boston through his work with Dorm Room Fund. In the past, Yasyf spent time as the Chief Software Architect at Foxtrot (“a 21st century approach to last mile logistics”), an engineer at Facebook and Square, and a Managing Partner at Dorm Room Fund Boston.

list.name: Angela Oduor Lungati
list.bio: Angela Oduor Lungati is a technologist, community builder and an open source software advocate. She is passionate about building and using appropriate technology tools to create impact in lives of marginalised groups. With over 10 years experience, she currently serves as the Executive Director at Ushahidi, a global non-profit technology company that builds tools for democratising information, increasing transparency and lowering barriers for individuals to raise their voices. She previously served as the Director of Community Engagement, creating and managing programs for Ushahidi’s diverse global community. She is also a co-founder at AkiraChix, a non-profit organisation that nurtures generations of women who use technology to develop innovations and solutions for Africa.

list.name: Jessica Li
list.bio: Jessica is an investor at Soma Capital (investments include Cruise, Rappi, Lambda School, Ironclad, Coda, Astranis) and head of content at Elpha (platform of 26K+ women in tech), Harvard in Tech, the Emerging VC Association, and Techstars Boston. She is a mentor with Alchemist, Techstars, Zane, and Loop and a venture scout with Gold Rush. She is one of Medium's Top VC Writers of 2020. Previously, she worked in VC with General Catalyst, Romulus Capital, Female Founders Fund, and Global Founders Capital; in startups with Morning Brew and Luxe (acquired by Volvo); and in investment banking at Morgan Stanley. She graduated with high honors from Harvard, where she completed her senior thesis with the 2016 Economics Nobel Laureate Oliver Hart.

list.name: Mark Ciaccio
list.bio: Dr. Ciaccio uses Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning to help accelerate Pharmaceutical Development at AbbVie Biopharmaceutical company. He is a member of the AbbVie RAIDERS (Rapid A.I. Developers) that are dedicated to the implementation of A.I. throughout the company. Mark specifically focuses on Clinical studies, currently working to simulate clinical trial enrollment, write chatbots to help answer regulatory questions, and design machine learning models to implement wearable devices in the clinic.

list.name: Aditya Agashe
list.bio: Aditya Agashe is a prominent Product Manager and the Author of the bestselling technology strategy book, Swipe to Unlock. He has been featured in the Wall Street Journal, Forbes, Business Insider, Inc. and more. He works on Azure cloud growth team to build hyper-converged and hybrid features that help customers adopt cloud technologies. He is the host of Product Alliance, and has previously managed product and engineering teams as the founder of Belle Applications and Head of Product at Speare.

list.name: Parth Detroja
list.bio: Parth Detroja is a distinguished Product Manager and the Author of the bestselling technology strategy book, Swipe to Unlock. He has been featured in the Wall Street Journal, Forbes, Business Insider, Inc. and more. Parth is currently a Product Manager at Facebook where he leads social music product efforts such as adding music to stories on Facebook and Instagram. He has previously worked product management and growth roles at other top tech companies including Microsoft, Amazon, and IBM.

list.bio: Example description

list.bio: Aaaaaaa

questions.question: Is registration open?
questions.answer: Yes! Be sure to click the link on the navigation bar to register!

questions.question: Who can attend?
questions.answer: Reflections | Projections is free and open to anyone regardless of age, major, or affiliation with the University of Illinois. Come join a discussion led by some of the brightest minds in the business about the bleeding edge of the tech industry!

questions.question: Is the conference free to attend?
questions.answer: Yes! Reflections | Projections is completely free to attend! This includes MechMania and all other events.

questions.question: Will I be able to attend the conference online?
questions.answer: We will be posting zoom links on our website so you can join our events wherever you are in the world! All events will be available online or in person. For speakers that choose to attend virtually, we will be playing the talk in a conference room to be viewed.

questions.question: Will I need to show proof of vaccination in order to attend the conference in person?
questions.answer: In accordance with University guidelines, you will either need to show proof of vaccination (through your safer Illinois app or using the vaccination card granted to you) or have proof of a negative test result shown through your Safer Illinois app.

questions.question: What precautions will Reflections|Projections take regarding the COVID pandemic?
questions.answer: Reflections|Projections is committed to keeping all conference participants safe, and ensuring that we adhere to university guidelines for the event. This includes masks indoors for even fully vaccinated individuals, pre-packaged food as opposed to open containers, providing hand sanitizer, cleaning conference rooms beforehand, and other precautions that we will discuss with the department in order to make this event possible.

questions.question: How will the career fair work?
questions.answer: We will be having a 1 day in-person, 1 day virtual career fair in order to make the event more accessible and adhere to university safety guidelines. More details regarding the platform and logistics will be communicated to attendees.

questions.question: What is MechMania?
questions.answer: MechMania is a 24-hour programming contest in which teams of students from various schools compete to create an AI capable of playing (and winning) a strategy game we have developed for the event. The competition dates and times will be announced soon! The competition will conclude with the closing ceremony and awards presentation, and will be livestreamed on twitch.tv. You must be registered for Reflections | Projections to compete in MechMania.

questions.question: Who's eligible?
questions.answer: We accept teams of up to four students. Our student competition accepts up to forty teams and pits them against each other in one final battle. Teams do not need to be comprised of all students from the same school, but all participants must be actively enrolled in a college or university.

questions.question: What do you need to know?
questions.answer: All members should be proficient in the programming language their team intends to use. The API will use JSON messages passed over HTTP, so we recommend having knowledge of a JSON library in your chosen language.

questions.question: What do you not need to know?
questions.answer: No prior knowledge of any specific languages are required. You won't need a background in artificial intelligence—in previous years, many teams without an AI background have competed and done well, or even won. You also shouldn't need knowledge of network programming beyond HTTP requests.

questions.question: What can you bring?
questions.answer: You can bring any reference manual(s) you wish, whether it be the Art of Computer Programming or the Art of War. But absolutely no outside code. You may, however, bring non-code items like rc files, build scripts, notes, etc. Competitors are required to bring their own laptops, though the code you write must be capable of running on our systems.

questions.question: What will you do?
questions.answer: By either starting from scratch or using our provided sample clients, you will build an artificial intelligence client to play a strategy game of our design. Our API will provide you information about the current state of the game, as well as allow you to send commands to play it. You may find previous competition sites useful to get an idea of how MechMania operates.

questions.question: What is PuzzleBang?
questions.answer: PuzzleBang is a puzzle hunt that takes place over the course of the Reflections|Projections week. Puzzles are released online at puzzlebang.com with the first puzzle coming out on Monday, September 21.  Expect one or two per day until Saturday when we release the final set of puzzles along with a metapuzzle.

questions.question: Who's eligible?
questions.answer: Anyone can play! We strongly recommend playing with friends, because the more the merrier. If you haven't met any friends who are interested in playing, drop us a line at GameControl@puzzlebang.com and we'll see about pairing you up with a new friend or two.

questions.question: What you will need to have?
questions.answer: Access to a functional human brain, an internet connection, a computer with a current web browser, and an open mind.  We're also adding video chat support this year, so a webcam or at least a microphone will enhance the experience.

questions.question: What do you need to know?
questions.answer: Everything! No, just kidding. Wikipedia's classical cipher's page might be useful. A number of letters in the alphabet, number of cards in a deck, all the US state abbreviations, and silly other things that you've probably run across in your daily life. Some awareness of the recent memes and popular culture will probably be helpful. Knowledge of current events at UIUC and the campus layout will be really helpful.

questions.question: What do you not need to know?
questions.answer: How to write code. It might be useful to be able to write a script to print out all the ways you can rearrange a set of letters, or apply different ciphers to them, but in general, you should be able to do everything by hand or ask Google and find a tool online to do it for you.

questions.question: What is the R|P Symposium?
questions.answer: The R|P Symposium is the outreach arm of the event focused on bringing computing concepts in a simple manner to K-12 classrooms. The goal is to use college student presentations to inspire younger students, especially those with fewer opportunities to be exposed to CS, to consider computing as a field.

questions.question: How do I register to present?
questions.answer: Fill out the form at acmrp.org/symposium and we'll be in touch with you soon!

questions.question: What is the motivation behind the R|P Symposium?
questions.answer: We stand by our commitment to serve the community and create a more diverse space within computing. By hosting symposium, we hope to support a more diverse generation of new computer scientists.

questions.question: Who can present?
questions.answer: You must be a current student at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign to present a project. This, along with a passion for your work, is all you need!

questions.question: How complex does my project need to be?
questions.answer: There is no level of complexity or intricacy we look for in the projects. All we ask is that it's something you're passionate about and willing to teach K-12 students.

questions.question: How long does my presentation need to be?
questions.answer: We ask that presentations be no longer than 10 minutes. If you are having trouble adhering to this limit, reach out to us at content@reflectionsprojections.org and we'd be more than happy to set up a time to work with you!

questions.question: I have a question that is not answered here.
questions.answer: Please email us at content@reflectionsprojections.org

questions.question: Our students have little to no exposure to computing. Are there any opportunities for such students?
questions.answer: Yes! Our lessons assume zero prior experience with computing.

questions.question: How long are each of these lessons?
questions.answer: Lessons are generally up to ten minutes in length per video.

questions.question: Do you have any recommendations for how students should interact with the material?
questions.answer: Following each lesson, we provide students with exercises and resources that we recommend students to try out if they want to learn more. If the lesson is part of a series of videos, we encourage you to work through them piece by piece, working on the recommended exercises and supplementary materials before moving on to the next one.

questions.question: Can I share these resources with others?
questions.answer: Absolutely! Our goal is to show as many people as we can that computing is an accessible field for everyone, so the more the merrier!

questions.question: My students have more questions. Are there any resources that we can direct them to for support?
questions.answer: Check out code.org and Khan Academy for online resources, or https://cs.illinois.edu/broadening-participation-computing/k-12-outreach for UIUC’s outreach programs.

questions.question: I have a question that is not answered here.
questions.answer: Please email us at content@reflectionsprojections.org

questions.question: What's the difference between Tech Talks and Speaker Talks?
questions.answer: Tech Talks are given by sponsor representatives who wish to spotlight their company and talk about new products/technologies. Speaker Talks are given by experts in the tech community and are about specific technical or personal topics.

questions.question: How will Speaker Talks be delivered?
questions.answer: Speaker talks will be livestreamed. Participants can interact and ask questions to speakers by utilizing the chat functionality of the streaming platform.

questions.question: Is there a career fair?
questions.answer: As a result of the transition to a virtual setting, there will not be a career fair at Reflections | Projections 2020. However, all company sponsors will get access to our resume book, so attendees may still use the conference as a recruiting opportunity.
